kimura: A powerful shoulder lock typically used from closed guard, side control, or north-south.
armbar: An elbow joint lock applied by isolating the opponent’s arm and hyperextending it, often from mount or guard.
triangle: A blood choke performed from guard by trapping the opponent's neck and one arm between your legs.
guillotine: A front headlock choke applied when the opponent’s head is low, commonly hit during takedown attempts.
omoplata: A shoulder lock using the legs, usually executed from closed guard or rubber guard.
rear naked choke: A choke applied from back control that compresses the carotid arteries using the arms.
americana: A shoulder lock that torques the arm outward, usually done from side control or mount.
anaconda: A choke that wraps around the opponent's neck and arm, generally set up from front headlock position.
darce: A choke where the arm threads under the opponent’s armpit and through the neck, locking up similar to an anaconda.
loop choke: A gi choke that uses your collar to wrap around the opponent’s neck, often from seated or standing grips.
bow and arrow choke: A powerful gi choke applied from back control by pulling on the collar while extending the opponent’s leg.
cross collar choke: A gi choke from guard or mount that uses both hands in the opponent’s collar to choke them.
x choke: A variation of the cross collar choke done from mount or closed guard by crossing the arms in the collar.
ezekiel choke: A gi choke done with your own sleeve while in mount or even inside closed guard.
straight ankle lock: A basic foot lock targeting the Achilles tendon, often done from Ashi Garami.
heel hook: A leg lock that attacks the knee via heel rotation; extremely dangerous and often no-gi only.
knee bar: A submission that hyperextends the knee, usually from top or bottom leg entanglements.
north south choke: A choke from north-south position using shoulder pressure and arm placement.
peruvian necktie: A flashy choke from front headlock where you step over the opponent’s head and sit back.
baseball bat choke: A gi choke using both sleeves like a bat grip, often from side control or knee on belly.
looping collar drag: A collar grip used to off-balance and sweep or take the back from seated guard.
lapel trap armbar: A setup using your own lapel to trap their arm for an armbar, typically in gi from guard or mount.
sumi gaeshi: A sacrifice throw from butterfly guard or seated position using underhooks.
back take from deep half: A transition where you rotate under and behind your opponent from deep half guard.
underhook sweep: A powerful sweep from half guard using an underhook and pressure into the opponent’s base.
over under pass: A tight pressure-based guard pass using one arm under and one over the opponent's legs.
knee slice pass: A dynamic guard pass that slices the knee across the thigh to establish side control.
